Publisherâ€™s Summary:
Daniel Cunha has a lot on his mind.

He got dumped by his pregnant girlfriend, his grandfather just dropped dead, and on the anniversary of the raid that doomed his drug-dealing aunt and uncle, his mother makes her unwanted return, years after she fled to marry another American fool like his father.

Misfortune, however, is a Cunha family affair, and no generation is spared. Not Danielâ€™s grandfather JoÃ£oâ€”poor JoÃ£oâ€”born to a prostitute and forced to raise his siblings while still a child himself. Not JoÃ£oâ€™s wife, Marta, branded as a bruxa, reviled by her mother, and dragged from her Ilha paradise by her scheming daughter, Maria. And certainly not Maria, so envious of her younger sisterâ€™s beauty and benevolence that she took her vicious revenge and fled to the States, abandoning her children: Daniel and Lucia, both tainted now by their half-Americanness and their motherâ€™s greedy absence.

Thereâ€™s poison in the Cunha blood. They are a family cursed, condemned to the pain of deprivation, betrayal, violence, and, worst of all, love. But now Maria has returned to grieve her father and finally make peace with Daniel and Lucia, or so she says. As New Yearâ€™s Eve nears, the Cunha family hurtles toward an irrevocable breaking point: a fire, a knife, and a death on the sands of Copacabana Beach.

Amid the cacophony of Rioâ€™s tumultâ€”rampant poverty, political unrest, the ever-present threat of violenceâ€”a fierce chorus of voices rises above the din to ask whether we can ever truly repair the damage we do to those we love in this â€œfiery debut novelâ€ (The Washington Post).

Olga Dies Dreaming

Olga is a wedding planner for some of New Yorkâ€™s most prominent families, and her brother Pedro is a well-known politician. While publicly it appears they are truly living the American dream, privately they each are holding secrets, including their radical mother who has suddenly come back into their lives. 

I had a hard time staying invested in the physical book, but really enjoyed it when I made the switch to audio. This book has a lot of depth - multi-dimensional characters, political and social issues woven throughout, and complex family issues. While this wasnâ€™t my normal read, I really enjoyed it.

ğŸ§ Audiobook review: Anita de Monte Laughs Last

One of my favorite audio performances of the year! Thanks @macmillan.audio for the gifted copy via Google Play.

Anitaâ€™s narration, performed by Jessica Pimentel, was an âœ¨experienceâœ¨. You could feel her rage oozing from the story. It was a hairs-standing-on-end, wincing-from-the-anger, punching-the-air with triumphâ€¦ visceral kind of performance.

Itâ€™s a dual timeline historical fiction, set in both 1985 and 1998. We meet Anita de Monte as sheâ€™s beginning to peak in the art world. Swept under the spell of a much older love interest, Anita gives up much of her dream to help Jack pursue his own success. Their relationship is volatile, both predictable and unpredictable until Anitaâ€™s death from a highrise fall in NYC.

Raquelâ€™s life more than a decade later mirrors Anitaâ€™s closely. A successful student of color in a historically white higher ed setting who falls for an older student with deep connections in the art world. Raquel uncovers a glimpse into Anita de Monteâ€™s life. Sheâ€™s been long forgotten by the art world, but the more her name is spokenâ€¦ the stronger Anita becomes. Sheâ€™ll be damned if she lets her philandering husband have the last word in her life. It has some supernatural vibes that will make you cackle. This book will make you angry, inspired, sad, but also hopeful.

Overall an excellent, multicast audio with all the stars for its production. Stacy Gonzalez as Raquel was great, and her confidence seemed to grow along with Raquelâ€™s, and Jonathan Gregg gives us Jackâ€™s pretentiousness with ease. Itâ€™s 13.5 hours and I listened at about 2.5x speed via Google play.

La candidata de la oligarquÃ­a, @xochitlgalvez, volviÃ³ a ponerse el pie, pues en un evento pÃºblico comentÃ³ que â€œsi a los 60 aÃ±os no has podido hacer un patrimonio eres bien gÃ¼ey, con todo respetoâ€. Estas palabras generaron repudio en redes sociales, por lo que las crÃ­ticas no han parado, ya que en el fondo esas palabras solo reflejan insensibilidad y arrogancia por parte de la candidata.

âœ¨Anita de Monte Laughs Last by Xochitl Gonzalezâœ¨

Genre: Fiction
Pages: 337

ğŸ“š1985. Anita de Monte, a rising star in the art world, is found dead in New York City; her tragic death is the talk of the town. Until it isnâ€™t. By 1998 Anitaâ€™s name has been all but forgottenâ€”certainly by the time Raquel, a third-year art history student is preparing her final thesis. On College Hill, surrounded by privileged students whose futures are already paved out for them, Raquel feels like an outsider. Students of color, like her, are the minority there, and the pressure to work twice as hard for the same opportunities is no secret.

But when Raquel becomes romantically involved with a well-connected older art student, she finds herself unexpectedly rising up the social ranks. As she attempts to straddle both worlds, she stumbles upon Anitaâ€™s story, raising questions about the dynamics of her own relationship, which eerily mirrors that of the forgotten artist.

ğŸ“This book was incredibly multi-layered. It addressed so many topics: art, identity, ambition, legacy, jealousy, privilege, and tradition. The through line theme was highlighting how Raquel faced the same obstacles that Anita did decades before - art is subjective and yet the gatekeepers are mostly white men. 

The story is told through 3 POVs: Anita, her famous artist husband Jack and Raquel, an art student writing her thesis on Jackâ€™s career. The timeline flipped back and forth from past to present, this allowed for a more effective comparison between our characters. Not only did Raquel mirror Anita, but even Raquel and Nickâ€™s relationship seemed to parallel that of Anita and Jack. As a reader, I was rooting for Raquel to break the cycle.

TIJUANA, MEXICO - APRIL 12: Claudia Sheinbaum, the leading Mexican presidential candidate of the Morena ruling party, arrived at a business luncheon at the Quartz Hotel in Tijuana on Friday, April 12, 2024 during her two day campaign tour of Baja California, Mexico. 

The candidate visited the municipality of Tijuana for an internal forum among businessmen in the morning and later in the day with a large rally of her supporters outside at the El Trompo Interactive Science Museum amphitheater.

Sheinbaum leads her two opposition rivals in national polls with 46 percent of support, the official candidate is 21 points ahead of Xochitl Galvez and 36 points ahead of Jorge Alvarez Maynez, if victorious she will be Mexicoâ€™s first woman president.

Anita De Monte Laughs Last
By: Xochitl Gonzalez
ğŸŒŸ ğŸŒŸ ğŸŒŸ ğŸŒŸ ğŸŒŸ 
The second I heard about this book, I wanted to read it. I thought it sounded so interesting and different from anything I've read in a long time. I love a character driven book and a deep dive into the art world. I thought the characters leaped off this page.I felt them in a real way as if they were blood and bone, and that's something you don't get every da in writing. The writing was haunting and beautiful and honest and raw at moments the way it spoke about relationships and abusive relationships the back and the forth and the all mightly pull between wanting more and wanting them. I loved seeing the flash backs to 1985 and Anita, she was a voice and string and powerful in her honestly and Raquel in 1998 and her learning who she wanted to become and we got to see that growth within her and I loved it. I cried multiple times in this book because I resonated with parts of these women's stories as a creator of art myself and as a woman who has survived abuse. I thought this novel was brave and beautiful and raw and spoke the truth of talent and art and beauty and these two women's stories blended so beautify together and created a epic novel that I will not forget. I highly recommend you check this out. I can tell already this will be one of the best books of the year for me.

Anita had life right where she wanted it, in her hands creating art and pushing boundaries within herself and her relationship that was all until one night in 1985 when she died and her story takes on a new tone she was up and coming and slowly forgotten. In 1996 , Raquel, a beautiful woman  at Brown University she feels her difference in everything she does. She knows who she is but wants to push to become something more something she deems better, art is her passion and through that passion she falls for a man who wants to take and we watch as two stories become one. As one woman's passions ended in death, another's will strive for excellence in her own way and when she learns of a woman long forgotten and her art. A woman so like her she will not let her or Anita be forgotten not again. #2024reads #5starreads #botm

There is a lot to love about Gonzalezâ€™s sophomore novel. The concept is perfection - dual timelines of a renegade Cuban artist and her untimely death versus a Puerto Rican art history student struggling to find her place at her Ivy League school who rediscovers her forgotten work. As expected, Gonzalezâ€™s writing is evocative and compelling.

My issue is that there is no subtly to be found. Everything is painted in stark black and white and the themes and ideas are repeated loudly and often. I wish Gonzalez trusted her readers with nuance and shades of gray.

â€œThe Mermaid Game,â€ the opening poem, â€œis dedicated to the 21 students and teachers who lost their lives on May 24, 2022 in a mass shooting at Robb Elementary in Uvalde, Texas.â€ â€œThe Mermaid Gameâ€ is a poem that heartbreakingly imagines a world where dead Brown children are still alive, where the threat of death does not haunt them. â€œIf I were a mermaid,â€ the speaker begins, then narrates scenes of childhood: â€œI would be forever summer / like ice cream trucks and cherry slush, / like two kids naÃ¯vely turning crisp / under the shallows of a three-foot pool.â€

However, this scene, too, shifts as the speaker-turned-mermaid considers:

[How] could I dream of the undrowned
children never aged. Brown, big-headed
babies alive in their schools, playing
clams with cousins, learning numbers
by octopus, all the while being protected
by whales and dolphins in a way that said
they were always safe.

A world where children never age is a sad one, but â€œBrown, big-headed / babies alive in their schoolsâ€ reminds us that nowhere is safe, not even schools. Perhaps especially schools. Bermejo describes the children as â€œundrowned,â€ which for her is a synonym for being alive. In placing the children underwater (â€œplaying clams,â€ â€œbeing protected by whales and dolphinsâ€), Bermejo takes their aliveness even further by creating a world where not only are they undrowned, but they are also undrownable.

The epigraph that precedes the poem is a quote from Alexis Pauline Gumbsâ€™s Undrowned: Black Feminist Lessons from Marine Mammals (2020). In signaling that the epigraph is from â€œAlexis Pauline Gumbs, Undrownedâ€ Bermejo emphasizes that Gumbs is also undrownedâ€”that is, aliveâ€”like the Brown children in Bermejoâ€™s utopian imaginary. Bermejo does the political work of linking histories of Black death and liveness with issues of Brown death and liveness in ways that speak to shared struggles without diminishing the specificity of either. Of course, AfroLatinidad also joins together these strugglesâ€¦â€

Renee Hudson in @lareviewofbooks on @xochitljulisa â€˜s use of Undrowned.  Looking forward to reading this prayer.

APRIL READING WRAP-UP!

Iâ€™ve been singing â€œApril showers bring May flowers!â€ for a good part of this month, so Iâ€™m hoping for some sunnier (and drier) skies in May. April was definitely a wet one! It was also a really good reading month for me. I finished the month with 20 books total, and three of them were five star reads! Not too shabby. Hopefully May brings more stunners along with those flowers. Favorites of the month include: The Mother Act, Crow Talk, Before We Were Strangers, Funny Story, The Sicilian Inheritance, Anita de Monte Laughs Last, and The Turtle House. Here are my ratings:

1. Daughter of a Promise 4/5
2. Annie Bot 4/5
3. Worry 4/5
4. All Fours 2/5
5. Jaded 4/5
6. Anita de Monte Laughs Last 4/5
7. Christa Comes Out of Her Shell 3.5/5
8. Darling Girls 4/5
9. Piglet 4/5
10. The Mother Act 5/5
11. Funny Story 4/5
12. Crow Talk 5/5
13. Before We Were Strangers 5/5
14. Friends in Napa 2/5
15. A Thousand Splendid Suns 4/5
16. The Turtle House 4/5
17. The Last Party 4/5
18. A Game of Lies 4/5
19. Bear 4/5
20. You Know What You Did 3.5/5
